metadata.titleEn: Dataset on atmospheric water cycle changes and the impact in a key area of the Tibetan Plateau under the background of global warming (2008)
metadata.description:
The assessment of changes in the atmospheric water cycle and the associated impacts in a key area of the Tibetan Plateau under the background of the global warming was a major component of the research project “The Environmental and Ecological Science of West China” run by the National Natural Science Foundation of China. The leading executive of the project was Xiangde Xu from the Chinese Academy of Meteorological Sciences. The project ran from January 2006 to December 2008.

The following data were collected by the project of the Sino-Japan Joint Research Center of Meteorological Disaster (JICA Project):
1. Observation category, time period and number of stations
1) JICA AWS data: From January to July of 2008, 73 automatic stations (including 5 automatic stations of the Chinese Academy of Sciences) collected data in Tibet, Yunnan, Sichuan and other provinces or autonomous regions. 
2) JICA GPS water vapour data: From January to October of 2008, 24 observation stations collected data in Tibet, Yunnan, Sichuan and other provinces or autonomous regions.
3) JICA encrypted observation GPS sonde data: From March to July of 2008, observations were made in Tibet, Yunnan, Sichuan and other provinces or autonomous regions (detailed observation time and location data can be found in the data catalogue).
2. Observation categories, data content
1) GPS water vapour
Data content: serial number, station name (Chinese), station number, longitude, latitude, altitude, year, month, day, time, surface pressure, surface air temperature, relative humidity, total delay (m), precipitation (cm) (Measurement interval: 1 hour).
2) GPS encrypted sonde
 Data content: air pressure P, temperature T, relative humidity RH, V component, U component, vertical height H, dew point temperature Td, water vapour content Mr, wind direction Wd, wind speed Ws, longitude Lon, latitude Lat, radar height RdH.
A value of "-999.90" means no observation data.
3) AWS
Data content: station number, longitude, latitude, elevation, site level, total cloud volume, wind direction, wind speed, sea level pressure, 3-hour pressure variable, past weather 1, past weather 2, 6-hour precipitation, low cloud form, low cloud volume, low cloud height, dew point, visibility, current weather, temperature, medium cloud form, high cloud form, 24-hour temperature variable, 24-hour pressure variable.

background: The tropopause is the transition between the troposphere and stratosphere; both have fundamentally different characteristics with respect to chemical processes and dynamical regimes. The tropopause acts as a “two‐way gate” for the exchange of mass, water vapor, and chemical species between troposphere and stratosphere. Since the vertical transport of water vapor and chemical compositions from the troposphere‐stratosphere exchange affects the radiative flux balance in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere, the tropopause plays an important role in the dynamical, radiative, and climate change. As a sensitive indicator of climate variability and global change, the tropopause height itself has received much attention in recent years. Using reanalysis data and climate model simulations, Santer et al. [2000, 2003] and Sausen and Santer [2003] pointed out that tropopause height is closely associated with tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling. During the last decades, the global mean tropopause height has shown an increase in reanalysis and radiosonde observations. However, either radiosonde or reanalysis data suffers from lower resolution and attendant biases. Over the Tibetan Plateau (TP hereafter), radiosonde stations are sparsely located in the eastern half where the average altitude is pretty low compared with the average elevation of the TP that is over 4500 m above sea level and sometimes called “the roof of the world.” The spatial and temporal scarcity of available observations limits the studies on the characteristics of the tropopause over the TP. As “the global water tower,” the TP is the main pathway for water vapor cross‐tropopause transport, which exerts a major influence on the energy balance of the Earth‐atmosphere system despite its low abundance in the stratosphere. Also, the TP is one of the most sensitive regions to global climate change.
research objective: In this study, we attempt to compare the tropopause height over the TP with that over the same latitudinal plain (hereinafter referred to as the Plain) on the basis of the Formosa Satellite 3 (FORMOSAT‐3)/Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) data.
challenges: However, either radiosonde or reanalysis data suffers from lower resolution and attendant biases. Over the Tibetan Plateau (TP hereafter), radiosonde stations are sparsely located in the eastern half where the average altitude is pretty low compared with the average elevation of the TP that is over 4500 m above sea level and sometimes called “the roof of the world.” In addition, the temporal frequency of radiosonde observations is also fairly low with 12 h intervals per day as well as substantial changes in instrumentation over time. The spatial and temporal scarcity of available observations limits the studies on the characteristics of the tropopause over the TP.
methods: In this study, the COSMIC temperature profiles from June 2006 to December 2009 with 100 m vertical resolution recorded in level 2 postprocessed wetPrf product provide by the UCAR COSMIC Data Analysis and Archive Center (CDAAC) are used. We only consider those profiles that pass quality control and all the valid profiles have been applied unweighted running average among five vertically adjacent points to reduce uncertainty stemming from RO measurements. In section 3, the climatological means, differences, and anomalies of temperatures over the TP (30°–35°N, 87°–95°E) and the Plain (30°–35°N, 112°–120°E) regions are compared. In section 4, a collocation requirement is employed to match the ROs in the Plain region with those in the TP region for further comparison. Using the valid data, we interpolate COSMIC RO retrieved temperatures to the radiosonde stations at the same levels. The comparisons of the temperatures from COSMIC and radiosondes are then made over the TP and the Plain, respectively.
dataset: Using Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC) radio occultation data from June 2006 to December 2009, the temperature structure and the tropopause height over the Tibetan Plateau (TP) is studied in this paper.
findings: The temperature over the TP is warmer and experiences a larger magnitude of change than that over the same latitudinal plain area (hereinafter referred to as the Plain) at the same level of lower troposphere. The lapse rate tropopause (LRT) shows a strong correlation with thermal properties of the atmosphere. Its height variation is anticorrelated with its temperature, highest at ∼19 km and coldest at approximately −72°C in boreal summer, but lowest at ∼13 km and approximately −56°C in boreal winter. The LRT height is also strongly dependent on the subtropical jet that is associated with the tropopause fold and/or multiple tropopauses, leading to fairly bimodal distribution of the LRT probability density function. As the “roof of the world,” the elevated topography of the TP dynamically lifts the CPT to a higher altitude without significantly seasonal variations. Along the latitude of 32.5°N the CPT is located at ∼18 km over the main body of the TP and drops to ∼15 km over the Plain. Given the area in the TP (30°–35°N, 87°–95°E) as well as in the Plain (30°–35°N, 112°–120°E), the CPT primarily resides at 17–18 km, 72.52% over the TP and 69.22% over the Plain. Their monthly mean difference can reach 1.4 km for the complete analysis period.

background: The land surface soil moisture is a crucial variable in weather and climate models. The soil moisture is an essential variable that governs the interactions between the land surface and the atmosphere. The soil moisture controls the ratio of the runoff to infiltration, controls the surface energy partition, and influences the development of vegetation and the carbon cycle. The soil moisture-precipitation feedback tendency has been identified. Satellite remote sensing provides the opportunity to measure the surface soil moisture at the regional, continental and even global scales. Passive microwave remote sensing provides a means for the direct measurement of the surface soil moisture at a coarse resolution and with a frequent temporal coverage. However, in the field of weather forecast and hydrology modeling, a finer temporal resolution would obviously improve the accuracy and reliability of the forecast. Numerical models can provide continuous estimates of soil moisture over the entire soil profile at any scale. However, due to the model initialization, the parameter and forcing errors, and the inadequate model physics and/or resolution, the model predictions are usually of low quality. The LDAS, which merges the observation information (which includes in situ measurements and satellite remote sensing data) into a dynamic model (i.e., LSM), is expected to provide high-quality surface energy and water flux estimates with adequate spatial coverage and resolution for weather forecast. Because the LDAS can make maximum usage of the observation data that are derived from satellite remote sensing, it is expected to improve the land surface water and energy simulations, especially in the ungauged and poorly gauged regions. The Tibetan Plateau plays an important role in the progression of the Asian summer monsoon through its strong land-atmosphere interactions; it also influences circulations over China, the Northern Hemisphere and even the entire globe. Understanding the land-atmosphere interaction over the plateau is essential for weather forecast and climate change studies.
research objective: The objective of this study was to develop an LDAS over the Tibetan Plateau by merging passive microwave remote sensing data and GCM output into a land surface model and to investigate the potential of the LDAS to improve the simulations of the land surface soil moisture and the energy flux.
challenges: This unstable performance was not an uncommon case for satellite retrievals, and hinders the application of the AMSR-E soil moisture products worldwide. We believe this result was caused by the strong forcing errors that were inherited from the biased rainfall input, and we suggest that reasonable forcing data are needed to properly estimate the temporal variations. Both the LDAS and the SiB2 overestimated the sensible heat flux, which is partly due to that LSM does not accounting for the excess resistance that is important for the sensible heat flux calculation (Yang et al., 2009), and should be addressed in future research.
methods: This system was applied over the Tibetan Plateau, using the National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) reanalysis data as forcing data and the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometers for EOS (AMSR-E) brightness temperatures as an observation. The AMSR-E brightness temperature data and the NCEP reanalysis data were assimilated into the SiB2. In order to evaluate the capability of the assimilation system, the LDAS products, the SiB2 simulations, the NCEP simulations, and the AMSR-E retrievals were compared against the in situ observations.
dataset: The data that were observed at the Gaize and Naqu stations were used in this study; these data were obtained from the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) China-Japan climate disasters mitigation project (JICA project). Gaize station (32◦18′N, 84◦06′E, 4416 m asl) is located in the middle of western Plateau, where the dry climate is dominant. Naqu station (32◦22′N, 91◦54′ E, 4509 m asl) is located in the central Plateau, and it experiences a wet climate condition during the monsoon season. The soil moisture that was measured with an horizontally installed TDR probe at a 5-cm depth from the surface was used for the surface soil moisture validation. The National Centers for Environmental Prediction/National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCEP/NCAR) reanalysis is a global reanalysis that was initiated in 1948 and continues to the near real-time at a horizontal resolution of T62 and a temporal resolution of 6 h. The brightness temperatures of the AMSR-E that were observed at 6.925 GHz and 18.7 GHz were used as the observation data in the LDAS.
findings: For the surface soil moisture, the LDAS simulations were superior to both NCEP and SiB2, and there was more than a one-third reduction in the root mean squared errors (RMSE) for both of the stations. Compared with the AMSR-E soil moisture retrievals, the LDAS simulations were comparable at the Gaize station, and they were superior at the Naqu station. For the whole domain inter-comparison, the results showed that the LDAS simulation of the soil moisture field was more realistic than the NCEP and SiB2 simulations and that the LDAS could estimate land surface states properly even in the regions where AMSR-E failed to cover and/or during the periods that the satellite did not overpass. For the surface energy fluxes, the LDAS estimated the latent heat flux with an acceptable accuracy (RMSE less than 35 W/m2), with a one-third reduction in the RMSE from the SiB2. For the 5-month whole plateau simulation, the LDAS produced a much more reasonable Bowen Ratio than the NCEP, and it also generated a clear contrast of the land surface status over the plateau, which was wet in the southeast and dry in the northwest, during the monsoon and post-monsoon seasons.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how passive microwave remote sensing is used in data collection methods for soil moisture over the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: In the study, the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometers for EOS (AMSR-E) brightness temperatures were used as an observation data source for the Land Data Assimilation System (LDAS) over the Tibetan Plateau to improve simulations of land surface soil moisture and energy flux.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset used to assess the water vapor transport characteristics over the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: The JICA GPS water vapor dataset, which includes parameters like ground pressure, ground temperature, relative humidity, total delay, and precipitable water, collected from 24 observation stations in Tibet, Yunnan, and Sichuan, helps assess water vapor transport characteristics over the Tibetan Plateau.

Feature Specification.Question: What features are typically included in a dataset related to water vapor measurements over the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: station name, station number, longitude, latitude, altitude, date, time, surface pressure, surface temperature, relative humidity, total delay, precipitable water

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary challenges associated with collecting high-resolution atmospheric data over the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: sparse distribution of radiosonde stations, lower resolution of existing data, potential biases, difficulty of obtaining high temporal frequency observations, elevated and remote terrain

Feature Specification.Question: What are the distinguishing features of datasets used to study land-atmosphere interactions over the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: passive microwave remote sensing data, GCM output, reanalysis data, in situ soil moisture measurements, high-quality estimates of surface energy and water fluxes, spatial and temporal variations

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from using passive microwave remote sensing data to estimate soil moisture in the Tibetan Plateau, and how can these be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using passive microwave remote sensing data for soil moisture estimation include the strong forcing errors inherited from biased rainfall inputs and the coarse resolution of satellite data. These challenges can be addressed by integrating satellite data with in situ observations and dynamic models through a Land Data Assimilation System (LDAS). This approach merges different data sources to enhance the accuracy and reliability of soil moisture estimates, particularly in ungauged and poorly gauged regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes limitations in the availability and quality of observations over the Tibetan Plateau, affecting studies on its atmospheric characteristics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations in the availability and quality of observations over the Tibetan Plateau are primarily due to the sparse distribution of radiosonde stations, particularly in the eastern half of the plateau where average altitudes are lower than the TP's overall elevation. The infrequent temporal coverage of radiosonde observations, typically every 12 hours, and substantial changes in instrumentation over time also contribute to these limitations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for merging passive microwave remote sensing data and GCM output into a land surface model over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Merging passive microwave remote sensing data and GCM output into a land surface model is necessary over the Tibetan Plateau to improve the simulation of land surface soil moisture and energy fluxes. This integration helps overcome limitations in temporal and spatial coverage, especially in ungauged and poorly gauged regions, providing high-quality surface energy and water flux estimates crucial for weather forecasting and climate change studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the errors in soil moisture retrieval from satellite data, and how do they affect the application of these data in weather forecasting models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in soil moisture retrieval from satellite data are often caused by strong forcing errors inherited from biased rainfall input. These errors can hinder the application of satellite-derived soil moisture products worldwide by affecting the accuracy of temporal variations. In weather forecasting models, such errors necessitate the use of reasonable forcing data to ensure reliable estimates of soil moisture and subsequent model predictions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of incorporating GPS-based water vapor measurements on the understanding of water vapor distribution over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating GPS-based water vapor measurements can enhance the understanding of water vapor distribution by providing high-resolution temporal data, which is crucial for studying the spatial and temporal scarcity of available observations over the Tibetan Plateau. This can lead to improved insights into the water vapor cross-tropopause transport and its influence on the Earth's energy balance.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of passive microwave remote sensing data with ground observations influence the accuracy of soil moisture predictions in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating passive microwave remote sensing data with ground observations can improve the accuracy of soil moisture predictions by reducing the root mean squared errors and providing more realistic soil moisture field simulations. This integration helps to overcome the limitations of satellite retrievals and model predictions, offering better temporal and spatial coverage.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of collecting GPS water vapor data across multiple stations in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand the water vapor characteristics and their variations in critical areas of the Tibetan Plateau, contributing to insights on the water cycle under global change conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to employ an LDAS system that merges satellite remote sensing data with GCM outputs in research over the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to improve simulations of land surface soil moisture and energy flux, which are crucial for understanding land-atmosphere interactions and enhancing weather forecasts and climate change studies in this sensitive region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can passive microwave remote sensing data be integrated into a land surface model to improve soil moisture simulations over the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration involves using the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometers for EOS (AMSR-E) brightness temperatures as observation data, which are then assimilated into the SiB2 model. This process is part of a Land Data Assimilation System (LDAS) that uses the AMSR-E brightness temperature data and the National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP) reanalysis data as forcing data to produce high-quality simulations of land surface soil moisture and energy flux.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered when using satellite retrievals for soil moisture estimation on the Tibetan Plateau and how can these be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include strong forcing errors from biased rainfall inputs that affect satellite retrievals. These can be addressed by using reasonable forcing data. Moreover, both the LDAS and SiB2 models overestimate sensible heat flux because they do not account for excess resistance, which should be considered in future research to improve accuracy.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate measurement of water vapor transport over high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of GPS water vapor profiles and GPS radio occultation data allows for accurate measurement of water vapor transport over the Tibetan Plateau, providing valuable insights into the atmospheric dynamics of such high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are typically encountered when employing satellite-based remote sensing for soil moisture estimation in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the influence of strong forcing errors from biased rainfall input and inadequate model physics, which can affect the accuracy and reliability of satellite-based soil moisture products in mountainous regions like the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods struggle to achieve adequate spatial and temporal resolution over the Tibetan Plateau, and what are some expected consequences of these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection methods over the Tibetan Plateau often face challenges due to the sparse distribution of radiosonde stations and the region's high altitude. This can lead to lower resolution and potential biases in the data, impacting the accuracy of studies on atmospheric and climate characteristics. As a result, researchers may expect difficulties in capturing detailed spatial and temporal variations of atmospheric phenomena.

Expectation.Question: What are the expectations for improving the accuracy of soil moisture data collection over the Tibetan Plateau, and why might current satellite retrieval methods fall short?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation is that by integrating satellite remote sensing data with dynamic models, such as in a Land Data Assimilation System (LDAS), the accuracy of soil moisture data collection can be improved. Current satellite retrieval methods may fall short due to strong forcing errors from biased rainfall input and inadequate model physics, which can lead to less reliable soil moisture estimates.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of using COSMIC radio occultation data for analyzing temperature structure over the Tibetan Plateau, and what challenges do researchers expect to encounter?
Expectation.Answer: The use of COSMIC radio occultation data is expected to provide high vertical resolution temperature profiles which can improve understanding of the temperature structure and tropopause characteristics over the Tibetan Plateau. However, researchers might encounter challenges related to ensuring data quality and managing the inherent uncertainty in radio occultation measurements, which could affect the precision of atmospheric analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using GPS water vapor and AWS data for understanding water cycle characteristics on the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of GPS water vapor and AWS data is effective in understanding the water cycle characteristics on the Tibetan Plateau due to the detailed observation content provided, such as total delay, precipitable water, and various atmospheric conditions measured at multiple stations. However, challenges such as spatial and temporal scarcity of data and potential biases in observations due to the high altitude and complex terrain must be addressed to fully leverage these data collection methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the challenges faced in collecting high-resolution atmospheric data over the Tibetan Plateau and suggest potential methods to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in collecting high-resolution atmospheric data over the Tibetan Plateau include the sparse distribution of radiosonde stations, which are mainly located in the eastern half of the plateau, and their low average altitude compared to the overall elevation of the region. Additionally, the temporal frequency of radiosonde observations is limited to 12-hour intervals, and there have been substantial changes in instrumentation over time. Potential methods to overcome these challenges include utilizing satellite-based systems like the Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC), which can provide high-resolution temperature profiles, and implementing more advanced data assimilation techniques to improve spatial and temporal coverage.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be integrated with land data assimilation systems (LDAS) to enhance soil moisture and energy flux simulations over the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could be integrated with LDAS to enhance simulations include passive microwave remote sensing data such as the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometers for EOS (AMSR-E) brightness temperatures, which provide surface soil moisture measurements. Additionally, global reanalysis datasets like the National Centers for Environmental Prediction/National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCEP/NCAR) reanalysis could be used as forcing data. The integration of these datasets with LDAS can improve the accuracy of soil moisture and energy flux simulations, especially in ungauged or poorly gauged regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methodologies for comparing tropopause height over different regions using satellite data and discuss their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: Methodologies for comparing tropopause height over different regions using satellite data include using the Formosa Satellite 3 (FORMOSAT-3)/COSMIC radio occultation data. This approach provides high-resolution temperature profiles, allowing for the comparison of tropopause height and temperature variations over the Tibetan Plateau and a similar latitudinal plain. The effectiveness of this method lies in its ability to capture the temperature structure and tropopause characteristics with higher accuracy than traditional radiosonde or reanalysis data, which suffer from lower resolution and biases. The COSMIC data's high vertical resolution enables detailed analysis of the lapse rate tropopause and its correlation with atmospheric thermal properties.
